Please note this is a double-feature. The other film is an adaptation of Tennesee William's Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, screening at 3:15 and 7:30 (more info below) which I will be passing on. If you are interested in seeing this as well, please indicate so when you RSVP, so you can meet-up with other group members.

Touch of Evil USA 1958 108 minutes

It's one of the truly great works of the American cinema, and it shows just what kind of excellence movies are capable of. Combustible Celluloid

...Welles' baroque border-town murder mystery is a wild masterpiece, a sleazy, grimy, jittery, and ultimately dazzling work of cinematic magic. Seattle Weekly


After the commercial disappointment and political controversy of Citizen Kane, Orson Welles was never given another opportunity to make a film with an entirely free hand in the United States. Touch of Evil was as close as he came...it's a strikingly constructed, visually audacious film that's also a great piece of popcorn entertainment.The justifiably famous opening shot -- a long tracking sequence that opens with a man planting a bomb in a car and ends with a newlywed Mexican DEA agent (Charlton Heston) and his bride (Janet Leigh) crossing the border -- is only the most spectacular bit of visual stunt work in this film; Welles seems to have having a grand time with his camera, and in its way this picture is just as visually exciting and inventive as Citizen Kane.This film is the work of a great artist having a lot of fun telling a good yarn, and it's wildly entertaining while still delivering the kind of excitement that only a real artist can deliver.

Touch of Evil was released in 1958 and brutally cut by the studio. This restoration (1998) is based on a 58-page memo written by Welles after he was barred from the editing room during the film's original post-production All Movie Guide

Here's a link to a complete review, including a couple of paragraphs of how this film was butchered in its original release: http://www.chicagorea...

And here is one for Cat on a Hot Tin Roof http://onfilm.chicago...

Hope to see you there,
Tom
